00022 #include "system.h"

00032 
00033 static char line[LINE_BUFFER_SIZE]; // Line to be executed. Zero-terminated.
00034 
00035 
00036 // Directs and executes one line of formatted input from protocol_process. While mostly
00037 // incoming streaming g-code blocks, this also directs and executes Grbl internal commands,
00038 // such as settings, initiating the homing cycle, and toggling switch states.
00039 // TODO: Eventually re-organize this function to more cleanly organize order of operations,
00040 // which will hopefully reduce some of the current spaghetti logic and dynamic memory usage. 
00041 static void protocol_execute_line(char *line) 
00042 {      
00043   protocol_execute_runtime(); // Runtime command check point.
00044   if (sys.abort) { return; } // Bail to calling function upon system abort  
00045 
00046   uint8_t status;
00047   if (line[0] == 0) {
00048     // Empty or comment line. Send status message for syncing purposes.
00049     status = STATUS_OK;
00050 
00051   } else if (line[0] == '$') {
00052     // Grbl '$' system command
00053     status = system_execute_line(line);
00054     
00055   } else {
00056     // Everything else is gcode. Send to g-code parser! Block if in alarm mode.
00057     if (sys.state == STATE_ALARM) { status = STATUS_ALARM_LOCK; }
00058     else { status = gc_execute_line(line); }
00059     
00060     // TODO: Separate the parsing from the g-code execution. Need to re-write the parser
00061     // completely to do this. First parse the line completely, checking for modal group 
00062     // errors and storing all of the g-code words. Then, send the stored g-code words to
00063     // a separate g-code executor. This will be more in-line with actual g-code protocol.
00064     
00065     // TODO: Clean up the multi-tasking workflow with the execution of commands. It's a 
00066     // bit complicated and patch-worked. Could be made simplier to understand.
00067   }
00068   
00069   report_status_message(status);
00070 }
00071 
00072 
00073 /* 
00074   GRBL MAIN LOOP:
00075 */
00076 void protocol_main_loop()
00077 {
00078   // ------------------------------------------------------------
00079   // Complete initialization procedures upon a power-up or reset.
00080   // ------------------------------------------------------------
00081   
00082   // Print welcome message   
00083   report_init_message();
00084 
00085   // Check for and report alarm state after a reset, error, or an initial power up.
00086   if (sys.state == STATE_ALARM) {
00087     report_feedback_message(MESSAGE_ALARM_LOCK); 
00088   } else {
00089     // All systems go!
00090     sys.state = STATE_IDLE; // Set system to ready. Clear all state flags.
00091     system_execute_startup(line); // Execute startup script.
00092   }
00093     
00094   // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------  
00095   // Main loop! Upon a system abort, this exits back to main() to reset the system. 
00096   // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------  
00097   
00098   uint8_t iscomment = false;
00099   uint8_t char_counter = 0;
00100   uint8_t c;
00101   for (;;) {
00102 
00103     // Process one line of incoming serial data, as the data becomes available. Performs an
00104     // initial filtering by removing spaces and comments and capitalizing all letters.
00105     while((c = serial_read()) != SERIAL_NO_DATA) {
00106       if ((c == '\n') || (c == '\r')) { // End of line reached
00107         line[char_counter] = 0; // Set string termination character.
00108         protocol_execute_line(line); // Line is complete. Execute it!
00109         iscomment = false;
00110         char_counter = 0;
00111       } else {
00112         if (iscomment) {
00113           // Throw away all comment characters
00114           if (c == ')') {
00115             // End of comment. Resume line.
00116             iscomment = false;
00117           }
00118         } else {
00119           if (c <= ' ') { 
00120             // Throw away whitepace and control characters
00121           } else if (c == '/') { 
00122             // Block delete not supported. Ignore character.
00123           } else if (c == '(') {
00124             // Enable comments flag and ignore all characters until ')' or EOL.
00125             iscomment = true;
00126           } else if (char_counter >= LINE_BUFFER_SIZE-1) {
00127             // Detect line buffer overflow. Report error and reset line buffer.
00128             report_status_message(STATUS_OVERFLOW);
00129             iscomment = false;
00130             char_counter = 0;
00131           } else if (c >= 'a' && c <= 'z') { // Upcase lowercase
00132             line[char_counter++] = c-'a'+'A';
00133           } else {
00134             line[char_counter++] = c;
00135           }
00136         }
00137       }
00138     }
00139     
00140     // If there are no more characters in the serial read buffer to be processed and executed,
00141     // this indicates that g-code streaming has either filled the planner buffer or has 
00142     // completed. In either case, auto-cycle start, if enabled, any queued moves.
00143     protocol_auto_cycle_start();
00144 
00145     protocol_execute_runtime();  // Runtime command check point.
00146     if (sys.abort) { return; } // Bail to main() program loop to reset system.
00147               
00148   }
00149   
00150   return; /* Never reached */
00151 }
00152 
00153 
00154 // Executes run-time commands, when required. This is called from various check points in the main
00155 // program, primarily where there may be a while loop waiting for a buffer to clear space or any
00156 // point where the execution time from the last check point may be more than a fraction of a second.
00157 // This is a way to execute runtime commands asynchronously (aka multitasking) with grbl's g-code
00158 // parsing and planning functions. This function also serves as an interface for the interrupts to 
00159 // set the system runtime flags, where only the main program handles them, removing the need to
00160 // define more computationally-expensive volatile variables. This also provides a controlled way to 
00161 // execute certain tasks without having two or more instances of the same task, such as the planner
00162 // recalculating the buffer upon a feedhold or override.
00163 // NOTE: The sys.execute variable flags are set by any process, step or serial interrupts, pinouts,
00164 // limit switches, or the main program.
00165 void protocol_execute_runtime()
00166 {
00167   uint8_t rt_exec = sys.execute; // Copy to avoid calling volatile multiple times
00168   if (rt_exec) { // Enter only if any bit flag is true
00169     
00170     // System alarm. Everything has shutdown by something that has gone severely wrong. Report
00171     // the source of the error to the user. If critical, Grbl disables by entering an infinite
00172     // loop until system reset/abort.
00173     if (rt_exec & (EXEC_ALARM | EXEC_CRIT_EVENT)) {      
00174       sys.state = STATE_ALARM; // Set system alarm state
00175 
00176       // Critical events. Hard/soft limit events identified by both critical event and alarm exec
00177       // flags. Probe fail is identified by the critical event exec flag only.
00178       if (rt_exec & EXEC_CRIT_EVENT) {
00179         if (rt_exec & EXEC_ALARM) { report_alarm_message(ALARM_LIMIT_ERROR); }
00180         else { report_alarm_message(ALARM_PROBE_FAIL); }
00181         report_feedback_message(MESSAGE_CRITICAL_EVENT);
00182         bit_false(sys.execute,EXEC_RESET); // Disable any existing reset
00183         do { 
00184           // Nothing. Block EVERYTHING until user issues reset or power cycles. Hard limits
00185           // typically occur while unattended or not paying attention. Gives the user time
00186           // to do what is needed before resetting, like killing the incoming stream. The 
00187           // same could be said about soft limits. While the position is not lost, the incoming
00188           // stream could be still engaged and cause a serious crash if it continues afterwards.
00189         } while (bit_isfalse(sys.execute,EXEC_RESET));
00190 
00191       // Standard alarm event. Only abort during motion qualifies.
00192       } else {
00193         // Runtime abort command issued during a cycle, feed hold, or homing cycle. Message the
00194         // user that position may have been lost and set alarm state to enable the alarm lockout
00195         // to indicate the possible severity of the problem.
00196         report_alarm_message(ALARM_ABORT_CYCLE);
00197       }
00198       bit_false(sys.execute,(EXEC_ALARM | EXEC_CRIT_EVENT));
00199     } 
00200   
00201     // Execute system abort. 
00202     if (rt_exec & EXEC_RESET) {
00203       sys.abort = true;  // Only place this is set true.
00204       return; // Nothing else to do but exit.
00205     }
00206     
00207     // Execute and serial print status
00208     if (rt_exec & EXEC_STATUS_REPORT) { 
00209       report_realtime_status();
00210       bit_false(sys.execute,EXEC_STATUS_REPORT);
00211     }
00212     
00213     // Execute a feed hold with deceleration, only during cycle.
00214     if (rt_exec & EXEC_FEED_HOLD) {
00215       // !!! During a cycle, the segment buffer has just been reloaded and full. So the math involved
00216       // with the feed hold should be fine for most, if not all, operational scenarios.
00217       if (sys.state == STATE_CYCLE) {
00218         sys.state = STATE_HOLD;
00219         st_update_plan_block_parameters();
00220         st_prep_buffer();
00221         sys.auto_start = false; // Disable planner auto start upon feed hold.
00222       }
00223       bit_false(sys.execute,EXEC_FEED_HOLD);
00224     }
00225         
00226     // Execute a cycle start by starting the stepper interrupt begin executing the blocks in queue.
00227     if (rt_exec & EXEC_CYCLE_START) { 
00228       if (sys.state == STATE_QUEUED) {
00229         sys.state = STATE_CYCLE;
00230         st_prep_buffer(); // Initialize step segment buffer before beginning cycle.
00231         st_wake_up();
00232         if (bit_istrue(settings.flags,BITFLAG_AUTO_START)) {
00233           sys.auto_start = true; // Re-enable auto start after feed hold.
00234         } else {
00235           sys.auto_start = false; // Reset auto start per settings.
00236         }
00237       }    
00238       bit_false(sys.execute,EXEC_CYCLE_START);
00239     }
00240     
00241     // Reinitializes the cycle plan and stepper system after a feed hold for a resume. Called by 
00242     // runtime command execution in the main program, ensuring that the planner re-plans safely.
00243     // NOTE: Bresenham algorithm variables are still maintained through both the planner and stepper
00244     // cycle reinitializations. The stepper path should continue exactly as if nothing has happened.   
00245     // NOTE: EXEC_CYCLE_STOP is set by the stepper subsystem when a cycle or feed hold completes.
00246     if (rt_exec & EXEC_CYCLE_STOP) {
00247       if ( plan_get_current_block() ) { sys.state = STATE_QUEUED; }
00248       else { sys.state = STATE_IDLE; }
00249       bit_false(sys.execute,EXEC_CYCLE_STOP);
00250     }
00251 
00252   }
00253   
00254   // Overrides flag byte (sys.override) and execution should be installed here, since they 
00255   // are runtime and require a direct and controlled interface to the main stepper program.
00256 
00257   // Reload step segment buffer
00258   if (sys.state & (STATE_CYCLE | STATE_HOLD | STATE_HOMING)) { st_prep_buffer(); }  
00259   
00260 }  
00261 
00262 
00263 // Block until all buffered steps are executed or in a cycle state. Works with feed hold
00264 // during a synchronize call, if it should happen. Also, waits for clean cycle end.
00265 void protocol_buffer_synchronize()
00266 {
00267   // Check and set auto start to resume cycle after synchronize and caller completes.
00268   if (sys.state == STATE_CYCLE) { sys.auto_start = true; }
00269   while (plan_get_current_block() || (sys.state == STATE_CYCLE)) { 
00270     protocol_execute_runtime();   // Check and execute run-time commands
00271     if (sys.abort) { return; } // Check for system abort
00272   }    
00273 }
00274 
00275 
00276 // Auto-cycle start has two purposes: 1. Resumes a plan_synchronize() call from a function that
00277 // requires the planner buffer to empty (spindle enable, dwell, etc.) 2. As a user setting that 
00278 // automatically begins the cycle when a user enters a valid motion command manually. This is 
00279 // intended as a beginners feature to help new users to understand g-code. It can be disabled
00280 // as a beginner tool, but (1.) still operates. If disabled, the operation of cycle start is
00281 // manually issuing a cycle start command whenever the user is ready and there is a valid motion 
00282 // command in the planner queue.
00283 // NOTE: This function is called from the main loop and mc_line() only and executes when one of
00284 // two conditions exist respectively: There are no more blocks sent (i.e. streaming is finished, 
00285 // single commands), or the planner buffer is full and ready to go.
00286 void protocol_auto_cycle_start() { if (sys.auto_start) { sys.execute |= EXEC_CYCLE_START; } }
